territory.long-form-name: Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands
territory.notes: First sighted by the Portuguese in the sixteenth-century. Following the Spanish-American war, Spain sold the islands to Germany under the terms of the German-Spanish Treaty of 1899. Japan took possession of the islands in 1914; the Treaty of Versailles and subsequently the League of Nations awarded the islands to Japan. Japan administered the islands as part of the South Pacific Mandate. Following World War II, the islands were administered by the United States as part of the UN Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands (agreement signed by Truman in 1947). The Truman administration transferred responsibility of the trusteeship to the Secretary of Interior in 1951. In 1978, the islands obtained a new constitution; a covenant agreement made the constitution fully effective on 4 November 1986.
